awd_titl_txt: Target Infusion Project: Integrating Data Science into the Urban Studies & Sustainability Curriculum at Winston-Salem State University
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Winston-Salem State University will enhance undergraduate education by adding data science content to the urban studies and sustainability curriculum and preparing students to meet the needs of the workforce or advanced studies in fields related to data science and urban studies.  

The project spans the department of computer science and the minor program in urban studies and sustainability. The project will modify two courses through the infusion of data science content which will orient students to current trends in urban studies; develop a new course - Applied Urban Studies Lab; engage undergraduates in urban studies related research; and establish an Urban Studies Lab. Undergraduate students are involved as research assistants and as teaching assistants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_street_address: 601 S MARTIN LUTHER KING JR DR

por.por_cntn:
HBCU-UP TIP Grant Project Outcomes Report:

Infusing Data Science into the Urban Studies & Sustainability Curriculum at Winston-Salem State University

Over the last three years, WSSU's Targeted Infusion Project has exposed more than 160 undergraduate students to the field of data science through the inclusion of activities, research projects, conferences, and classroom lectures in the Urban Studies and Sustainability program.  The grant related activities included with the project also provided professional growth and advancement for the faculty included through the development of data science modules, presentations at conferences, exposure to new technologies, and working with the projects undergraduate research assistants since Fall 2019.  

The broader impacts of this project are numerous.  First, several methods of dissemination of the results have been developed including a website has been online since Summer 2020. The website has provided an outlet for the dissemination of the modules developed as part of the grant.  Additionally, the website provided a mechanism by which the public can be informed of the intent, activities, and successes of the project at WSSU.  The outcomes of the grant have also been shared through numerous scholarly endeavors including presentations at several national and regional conferences/workshops, poster presentations and panel discussions.

A second impact of the project has been the involvement of undergraduate students in research activities associated with data science and Urban Studies & Sustainability.  Over the three-year period in which this project was carried out, a total of 8 undergraduate research assistants (all female, all African American) were employed by the project and actively participated in the project. These students helped to administer surveys, collect data, build and test course modules, analyze data and present findings at conferences.  Two of the students have been recently hired to positions that will enable them to use the research skills and data science techniques they learned during the grant.

As mentioned earlier, more than 160 undergraduate students at WSSU directly benefited from the grant through the inclusion of course specific modules that engaged students with data science skills and techniques, ranging from excel, pivot tables to Python and GIS applications.  Additionally, these students utilized these skills in the development of research projects that witnessed them collect, clean, analyze and present data on a wide variety of urban studies/sustainability related topics.  Finally, through the development of a new course offering, Applied Urban Studies Lab, students received 'hands on' training with a wide variety of technologies for the collection and analysis of information on the urban environment.  This included air and water quality technology, web-based GIS applications and an assortment of data analysis software.

Through both the employment of undergraduate research assistants and interacting with WSSU students in the classroom, this project has exposed women, minorities, and underrepresented students at WSSU (an HBCU) to data science through content added to urban studies and sustainability courses, and as a result, increased the size and diversity of the STEM workforce.  While less than originally anticipated, the number of minors in the Urban Studies & Sustainability Program has been increasing in the last year.  Likewise, students expressed an interest in learning more about data science according to the survey administered to students in the courses impacted by the grant.  

The enhanced infrastructure that helped to create the Urban Studies Lab at WSSU is a final, lasting, broader impact of the project.  Through the funding received from NSF as part of the HBCU-UP TIP grant, 25 new desktop computers were purchased and installed in the lab for student engagement with data science through the Urban Studies & Sustainability curriculum. Additionally, air quality sensors and water quality sensors and instrumentation were purchased and employed in the lab to actively engage students with 'hands on' activities to enhance their understanding and skills related to data science.  In the end, the enhanced infrastructure located within the dedicated Urban Studies Lab has created a workspace for student engagement, research and learning that is critical to growing student interest in STEM fields related to Urban Studies & Sustainability.

WSSU's Target Infusion Project, Integrating Data Science into the Urban Studies and Sustainability Curriculum has provide unique and needed opportunities for African American and largely female students.  Even in the face of a global pandemic, courses were infused with new modules to provide students opportunities to engage with a wide variety of data science skills, new technologies were obtained and incorporated into the curriculum, a new class was created and offered, and more than a dozen scholarly presentations were given by faculty and undergraduate research assistants over the three-year period.   

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2022
Modified by: Russell Smith

WSSU's Target Infusion Project, Integrating Data Science into the Urban Studies and Sustainability Curriculum has provide unique and needed opportunities for African American and largely female students.
